column4: canâ€™t take the subway like what can you do ğŸ˜ hey so without minimizing the terror of what happened tonight
column5: i want to share this video
column6: where vox producer carlos maza talks about how the way terrorism is covered by the media enhances and alters the way that we perceive terrorism. basically he says that when you turn on cable news and see 24-hour news coverage of an incident and the same violent footage over and over
column7: your brain starts to think that terrorism is commonâ€”when in actuality
column8: the chances of you or someone you know being involved in a terrorist attack are really
column10: really small.Â  itâ€™s also important to remember that news networks make money off of views during coverage of terrifying events: the more a news network sensationalizes an event
column11: the more they show horrifying footage
column12: the more they interview visibly shaken witnessesâ€¦ the harder itâ€™s going to be for their viewers to look away. which leads to more money for them
column13: and increased fear in communities (which is then exploited by politicians through fear mongering and what security expert bruce schneier
column14: who is interviewed in the video
column15: callsÂ â€œsecurity theaterâ€). i found whatâ€™s said in this video to be comforting because itâ€™s really easy to come away from a night of news coverage like we had tonight and be afraid. it would be really easy for me to work myself up tonight and go to work tomorrow and watch my classroom fill with students and wonder how many of them will make it to adulthood
column16: because this and that and the other thing. it would be really easy for me to think that everything is futile because the world is so fucked up that the little things we do arenâ€™t going to matter in the long run
column17: but that kind of thinking isnâ€™t healthy. iâ€™m not saying that itâ€™s wrong to be afraid. we are living in a bizarre
column18: upside-down world full of things to be afraid of. i want to echo what maza and schneier say in the video: you have to be a skeptical consumer of news. you have to remember who produces the news you watch and why they do it. but even more than that
column19: you have to protect your heart
column20: and you have to keep yourself from operating out of a place of fear.Â  terrible things happen every day. we have to talk about them and we have to give them the respect they deserve and we have to figure out why they happened and how we can stop them from happening again. and we have to resist the urge to let fear dictate our actions. column1: iviarelle 161017982596 "2017-05-24 11:16:49 GMT" https://iviarelle.tumblr.com/post/161017982596/why-you-should-not-dismiss-research-unless-you-rly "bisexualbaker:  jamyesterday:  downtroddendeity:  sidereanuncia:  tvatemybrain:  jedusaur:  Internet
column2: I am a queer researcher of queer health and I have something to say. A few weeks back
column3: a study went viral about the relationship between marriage equality policy and queer teen suicide rates
column4: and a lot of people reacted thusly:Â â€œqueer mental health is better when weâ€™re not discriminated against! BREAKING: SKY IS BLUE
column5: WATER IS WETâ€ This happens a lot. People see research about a thing ~Everyone Already Knows~ and they mock it. Now I want to make two things really clear: 1. Everyone does not already know. 2. This shit can lose these projects their funding. Did you know that media coverage is a crucial factor in funding allocation? When we submit our application for grant renewal
column6: we have to provide a list of news articles about our research so they can decide whether the public cares enough about us to let us keep doing our work. And most research doesnâ€™t get all that much coverage
column7: so individual reactions can really matter. If the primary reaction to our publications is eyerolling
column8: we legitimately might not be able to continue. Iâ€™ve seen some frustration from people who believe this research funding would be better put to use â€œactually helpingâ€ the affected populations instead ofâ€“I donâ€™t know
column9: pinning them under microscopes or whatever it is they think we do. But funding for policy initiatives is driven by research. I know you wish politicians would listen to individual voices telling them where the problems are
column10: but thatâ€™s honestly not a smart way to direct limited resources. We need solid evidence. And a lot of the areas that need the most attention arenâ€™t obviousâ€“who knew bisexual people are at a much higher risk for physical and mental health disparities than gay and lesbian people? Who would have guessed that transgender folks are more likely than any other group (including straight people) to be military veterans
column11: but overwhelmingly donâ€™t claim their benefits? Iâ€™m sure some people noticed these patterns
column12: but they definitely werenâ€™t common knowledge within the queer communities Iâ€™ve grown up around
column13: and those findings are leading to direct action as we speak. I get that it can be frustrating to feel like your identity is being reduced to facts and figures for the benefit of red tape. But trust me
column14: the researchers arenâ€™t your enemy here. Most of us are queer too. All of us are just as frustrated by this crap as you are. We are doing our best
column15: and I swear to you this work really is making a difference. Please donâ€™t sabotage it.  Iâ€™m reblogging this because it only has 9 notes
column17: REALLY have a lot more.  Also
column18: given the current US administrationâ€™s plan to stop collecting data on LGBTQ identities as part of the census
column19: we are in need of accurate
column20: useful data now more than ever.   Plus the ability to cite peer-reviewed evidence of these sorts of things and quantify the extent of â€œobviousâ€ effects can be pretty important to researchers who are working in adjacent fields that donâ€™t produce the sorts of headline soundbites that get mocked on social media. And often headlines and summaries are misleading and reductive- a study about wage gaps across a variety of demographics might get headlined â€œWomen Still Make Less Than Men
column21: New Study Showsâ€ when the bulk of the paper is about the intersection of race and gender identity
column22: and Iâ€™ve seen people on Tumblr mocking a study about the flavor compounds in food across the Indian subcontinent
column23: conducted by Indian scientists at an Indian university
column24: as â€œLOL white people donâ€™t know how to cook.â€  And to add to thisâ€“ itâ€™s also important to be able to point to something and say
column26: the problem is not that these people arenâ€™t straight. Being able to point to actual science that says
column29: itâ€™s you and how you treat usâ€â€“ well
column30: thatâ€™s a a good thing.  There are a lot of people out there who genuinely believe that being any  flavour of queer is intrinsically harmful to you. That unhappiness is a  natural result of being gay
column31: that to be trans is to be mentally ill
column32: that bisexuals are confused and troubled.Â There are people who believe that you cannot be happy or well if youâ€™re queer
column33: and not all of those people are bad people. Some of them have what they perceive to be your best interests at heart
column34: and they want you to be happy
column37: emotionally and mentally safe. And they still act in a way that causes harm
column39: isolates kids and tells them that pain is what they should expect for being who they are. Itâ€™s important to be able to say
column46: it does matter what you do.â€  Science: Because bigots donâ€™t tend to believe the people theyâ€™re bigoted against when we way something hurts us. " False text

iviarelle 161054510176 "2017-05-25 11:24:28 GMT" https://iviarelle.tumblr.com/post/161054510176/cannabidiol-reduces-seizures-in-kids-with-severe "mindblowingscience:  A cannabis compound has been proven for the first time to reduce the frequency of seizures in people with a rare
column2: severe form of epilepsy
column3: according to the results of a randomized trial. For years
column4: parents have pointed to anecdotal benefits of cannabidiol (CBD)
column5: a compound in the marijuana plant that does not produce a high
column6: saying it reduces seizures in treatment-resistant epilepsy. Now doctors have performed a randomized trial to show cause and effect
column7: with the findings published in Wednesdayâ€™s issue of the New England Journal of Medicine. To conduct the study
column8: the researchers focused on Dravet syndrome
column9: a rare form of epilepsy that begins in infancy and is linked to a particular mutation that often resists combinations of up to 10 conventional seizure medications. They enrolled 120 patients who ranged in age from 2.5 to 18 years. Sixty-one patients were randomly assigned to cannabidiol
column10: and the 59 others to placebo. Neither the researchers nor the families knew who received the medication to prevent bias. All continued to take their existing medications. â€œThe message is that cannabidiol does work in reducing convulsing seizures in children with Dravet syndrome
column11: â€ said lead author Dr. Orrin Devinksy
column12: who is director of NYUâ€™s Langone Comprehensive Epilepsy Center. For those in the cannabinoid group
column13: the median number of convulsive seizures per month dropped from 12.4 per month before treatment
column15: the researchers reported. The placebo group
column17: only saw their convulsive seizures fall from 14.9 per month

column1: iviarelle 161036317411 "2017-05-24 22:50:34 GMT" https://iviarelle.tumblr.com/post/161036317411/scientists-find-simple-copper-complex-shuts-down "mindblowingscience:  Botulinum neurotoxin is probably best known to Americans as BOTOX
column2: a cosmetic medicine
column3: rather than as a cause of potentially dangerous foodborne illnesses. Lesser known is that Clostridium botulinum
column4: the bacterium that causes the neurointoxication
column5: produces one of the most potent toxins on earth and is classified as a potential bioterrorism threat. While no cure existsâ€”and botulism treatment options are limitedâ€”a serendipitous discovery by scientists at The Scripps Research Institute (TSRI) may provide a new therapy that can stop the neurotoxin even in its more severe
column6: advanced stages of action. The finding
column7: based on rodent studies
column8: was published recently in the Journal of the American Chemical Society. Lead scientist Kim Janda
column10: Jr. Professor of Chemistry at TSRI
column11: said he decided to explore botulism neurotoxin due to its debilitating and life-threatening effects
column12: as well as its danger as a potential bioterrorism agent. â€œItâ€™s on the same level as Anthrax

column1: iviarelle 160871976401 "2017-05-20 13:10:16 GMT" https://iviarelle.tumblr.com/post/160871976401/lyme-disease-is-on-the-rise-in-ontario-heres "starryroom: nuclearmu5hroom:  ominouspotato:  allthecanadianpolitics:   Ontario public health officials are asking residents to watch out for ticks

column7: which is how Lyme disease is transmitted. DO use a pair of tweezers to grasp the tick as close to your skin as possible
column8: and pull straight out.  DONâ€™T PULL THE TICK!!! if you grab it and the head breaks off
column9: youâ€™re screwed.  COVER THE TICK IN VASELINE OR NEOSPORIN! The tick will suffocate and pull itself out in seconds. column12: etc. Ticks only need to breathe between 3 and 15 times per hour. They have very low oxygen requirements

The Rice battery stores lithium in a unique anode
column2: a seamless hybrid of graphene and carbon nanotubes. The material first created at Rice in 2012 is essentially a three-dimensional carbon surface that provides abundant area for lithium to inhabit. The anode itself approaches the theoretical maximum for storage of lithium metal while resisting the formation of damaging dendrites or â€œmossyâ€ deposits. Dendrites have bedeviled attempts to replace lithium-ion with advanced lithium metal batteries that last longer and charge faster. Dendrites are lithium deposits that grow into the batteryâ€™s electrolyte. If they bridge the anode and cathode and create a short circuit
column3: the battery may fail
column4: catch fire or even explode.  Continue Reading. " False link
